title: Isaiah Chapter 49 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 49 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 49 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 49.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:3, who is called God's servant?
options: Israel
Judah
Ephraim
David
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:3 says, 'Thou art my servant, O Israel, in whom I will be glorified.'

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:1, from where has the LORD called the speaker?
options: From the womb
From the mountains
From the desert
From the city
questions.correctAnswer: From the womb
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:1 states that the LORD called the speaker 'from the womb; from the bowels of my mother hath he made mention of my name.'

questions.question: What does Isaiah 49:2 say the LORD made the speaker's mouth like?
options: A sharp sword
A burning fire
A mighty shield
A flowing river
questions.correctAnswer: A sharp sword
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:2 describes the LORD making the speaker's mouth 'like a sharp sword.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 49:4 expresses a feeling that the speaker's labor was in vain.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:4 says, 'I have laboured in vain, I have spent my strength for nought, and in vain.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:6, what additional role will the servant have besides raising up the tribes of Jacob?
options: A light to the Gentiles
A king over Israel
A prophet to the nations
A priest in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: A light to the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:6 states the servant will be 'a light to the Gentiles, that thou mayest be my salvation unto the end of the earth.'

questions.question: Who does Isaiah 49:7 say will worship because of the LORD's faithfulness?
options: Kings and princes
Priests and prophets
The poor and needy
The elders and judges
questions.correctAnswer: Kings and princes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:7 says 'Kings shall see and arise, princes also shall worship.'

questions.question: What does the LORD promise to do in an acceptable time according to Isaiah 49:8?
options: Hear and help
Send a prophet
Destroy enemies
Build a temple
questions.correctAnswer: Hear and help
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:8 says, 'In an acceptable time have I heard thee, and in a day of salvation have I helped thee.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:10, who will lead those who shall not hunger nor thirst?
options: He that hath mercy on them
The king of Israel
The mighty warrior
The prophet Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: He that hath mercy on them
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:10 states, 'for he that hath mercy on them shall lead them.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 49:14 shows Zion saying the LORD has forsaken and forgotten her.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:14 says, 'But Zion said, The LORD hath forsaken me, and my Lord hath forgotten me.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 49:15: 'Can a woman forget her sucking child, that she should not have ______ on the son of her womb?'
options: compassion
anger
joy
fear
questions.correctAnswer: compassion
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:15 asks, 'Can a woman forget her sucking child, that she should not have compassion on the son of her womb?'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:16, where has God graven His people?
options: Upon the palms of His hands
On the stones of the altar
On the gates of Jerusalem
On the tablets of stone
questions.correctAnswer: Upon the palms of His hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:16 states, 'Behold, I have graven thee upon the palms of my hands.'

questions.question: Who will bring the sons and daughters in their arms according to Isaiah 49:22?
options: The Gentiles
The priests
The kings of Israel
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:22 says, 'I will lift up mine hand to the Gentiles... and they shall bring thy sons in their arms, and thy daughters shall be carried upon their shoulders.'

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 49:25 says the LORD will save the children of those who contend with His people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:25 says, 'I will contend with him that contendeth with thee, and I will save thy children.'

questions.question: What will happen to those that oppress God's people, according to Isaiah 49:26?
options: They will be fed with their own flesh and drunken with their own blood
They will be lifted up and honored
They will be forgiven and restored
They will be blinded and lost
questions.correctAnswer: They will be fed with their own flesh and drunken with their own blood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:26 states, 'I will feed them that oppress thee with their own flesh; and they shall be drunken with their own blood.'

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:12, from which directions will people come?
options: From the north, west, and the land of Sinim
From the east, south, and the land of Egypt
From the mountains, valleys, and rivers
From the cities, fields, and deserts
questions.correctAnswer: From the north, west, and the land of Sinim
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:12 says, 'these shall come from far: and, lo, these from the north and from the west; and these from the land of Sinim.'

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 49 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 49 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels their efforts in serving God are in vain. Based on Isaiah 49, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them about perseverance?
options: Their work is with God and will be rewarded in His timing
They should stop serving because their labor is meaningless
God is silent and does not see their efforts
They must work harder to prove their worth
questions.correctAnswer: Their work is with God and will be rewarded in His timing
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:4 shows the servant expressing feeling labored in vain, but he trusts that his judgment is with the LORD and his work with God. This encourages perseverance, trusting God's timing and purpose. See also verses 5 and 6, where God affirms the servant's role and strength.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49 teach about God’s faithfulness in times of feeling forgotten or forsaken?
options: God will never forget His people and shows compassion like a mother to her child
God abandons people when they feel forsaken
God’s people must earn His remembrance by good works
God only remembers those who are always faithful
questions.correctAnswer: God will never forget His people and shows compassion like a mother to her child
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:14-15 emphasizes that although Zion feels forsaken, God compares His compassion to that of a mother who cannot forget her nursing child, affirming His unfailing remembrance and mercy.

questions.question: When a believer is struggling with doubt about their identity and purpose, what does Isaiah 49 reveal about God's calling and purpose?
options: God calls His servant from the womb and plans for them to be a light to the nations
People discover their purpose only through personal effort
God’s calling is uncertain and changes with circumstances
Identity is determined by social status
questions.correctAnswer: God calls His servant from the womb and plans for them to be a light to the nations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:1-6 reveals that God calls His servant from the womb and appoints him to restore Israel and be a light to the Gentiles, showing that God’s calling is purposeful and eternal.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49 encourage believers to rely on God’s strength rather than their own?
options: God is the servant’s strength even when Israel is not gathered
Believers should rely solely on their own efforts
Strength comes from earthly achievements
Believers must depend on others more than God
questions.correctAnswer: God is the servant’s strength even when Israel is not gathered
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:5 shows the servant acknowledging that although Israel is not gathered, God will be his strength, teaching reliance on divine strength over human circumstances.

questions.question: A believer is called to evangelism but feels inadequate. What truth from Isaiah 49 can encourage them regarding the scope and purpose of their witness?
options: God’s servant is not only to restore Israel but to be a light to the Gentiles to the ends of the earth
Evangelism is only for the spiritually gifted
Witnessing is optional in Christian life
The gospel is only for Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God’s servant is not only to restore Israel but to be a light to the Gentiles to the ends of the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:6 explains that the servant’s mission extends beyond Israel to the Gentiles, encouraging believers that their witness has a vast and purposeful scope.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49 instruct believers about God’s care for those who face hardship and captivity?
options: God promises freedom and provision even to prisoners and those in darkness
God ignores those in captivity
Believers must earn their release through works
Captivity is permanent with no hope
questions.correctAnswer: God promises freedom and provision even to prisoners and those in darkness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:8-9 shows God’s promise to help and preserve His servant, enabling him to proclaim freedom to prisoners and light to those in darkness, highlighting God’s care and deliverance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about God’s guidance in times of need can a believer learn from Isaiah 49?
options: God leads His people with mercy to springs of water so they shall not hunger or thirst
Believers must find their own way without expecting divine help
Provision depends on human effort alone
Trials mean God has abandoned His people
questions.correctAnswer: God leads His people with mercy to springs of water so they shall not hunger or thirst
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:10 teaches believers that God’s mercy provides guidance and sustenance, assuring that He cares deeply for their physical and spiritual needs.

questions.question: True or False: According to Isaiah 49, God’s promises include restoring desolate places and increasing the number of inhabitants.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:19-20 promises that desolate and destroyed lands will be inhabited again and become too small for the growing population, symbolizing God’s restoration and blessing.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 49 teaches that God will contend and save His people even against mighty oppressors.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:25-26 assures believers that God will fight on their behalf against powerful enemies and deliver them, showing His protective power and faithfulness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Isaiah 49 compares God’s remembrance of His people to a mother who cannot forget her ________ child.
options: sucking
weaned
lost
rebellious
questions.correctAnswer: sucking
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:15 uses the analogy of a mother who cannot forget her sucking child to illustrate God’s unfailing compassion and remembrance of His people.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49 encourage humility and trust in God’s sovereign plan when one faces rejection or despising by others?
options: God’s servant may be despised and abhorred by nations, but kings and princes will honor him because of the LORD’s faithfulness
One should retaliate against those who despise them
Rejection means God has abandoned them
Humility is unnecessary if one is rejected
questions.correctAnswer: God’s servant may be despised and abhorred by nations, but kings and princes will honor him because of the LORD’s faithfulness
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:7 teaches that even when despised by men, God’s servant will be honored by rulers because of God’s faithfulness, encouraging believers to trust God’s sovereign plan rather than retaliate.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 49 teach about God’s personal care and intimate knowledge of His people?
options: God has engraved His people on the palms of His hands and continually remembers their walls
God is distant and unaware of individual lives
God only cares about the community, not individuals
God’s knowledge is limited to public actions
questions.correctAnswer: God has engraved His people on the palms of His hands and continually remembers their walls
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:16 depicts God’s deep, personal care by saying He has graven His people on the palms of His hands, symbolizing constant remembrance and protection.

questions.question: Based on Isaiah 49, how should believers respond in times of waiting and hope for God’s promises?
options: They should wait confidently and not be ashamed, knowing the LORD is faithful
They should give up hope if promises are delayed
They should rely on human strength to force outcomes
They should doubt God’s promises
questions.correctAnswer: They should wait confidently and not be ashamed, knowing the LORD is faithful
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:23 encourages believers that those who wait on the LORD will not be ashamed because God is faithful, teaching confident patience in God’s timing.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49 teach about God’s provision and restoration for those in spiritual or physical desolation?
options: God will make highways and mountains a way, and people will come from far to be restored
Desolation is permanent with no hope of restoration
People must restore themselves without God’s help
Restoration depends only on human planning
questions.correctAnswer: God will make highways and mountains a way, and people will come from far to be restored
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:11-12 shows God making paths for His people and gathering them from far places, symbolizing divine restoration and provision.

questions.question: What lesson does Isaiah 49 teach about God’s justice toward oppressors of His people?
options: God will feed oppressors with their own flesh and make them drunk with their own blood
God ignores injustice
Oppressors have the final victory
Justice is only human responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: God will feed oppressors with their own flesh and make them drunk with their own blood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:26 describes God’s ultimate justice by punishing oppressors in a vivid metaphor, assuring believers of His righteous vindication.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 49 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 49.

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:6, the servant is called to be a light to the Gentiles. Which New Testament event most directly fulfills this prophetic role?
options: The Pentecost and the coming of the Holy Spirit
The baptism of Jesus by John the Baptist
The Great Commission to make disciples of all nations
The Transfiguration of Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: The Great Commission to make disciples of all nations
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:6 foretells the servant being a light to the Gentiles, which is fulfilled in the New Testament by Jesus' command to his disciples to go and make disciples of all nations (Matthew 28:19-20).

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Isaiah 49:15 where God compares His remembrance of His people to a mother's compassion for her child?
options: Simile
Metaphor
Hyperbole
Irony
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:15 uses a simile, comparing God's compassion to that of a woman for her sucking child, to emphasize His unfailing care.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:2 refers to the servant’s mouth as a 'sharp sword.' What does this metaphor most likely signify in the context of prophetic literature?
options: The power and decisiveness of the servant’s words
The servant’s role as a warrior
The servant’s authority to execute judgment physically
The servant’s ability to defend himself
questions.correctAnswer: The power and decisiveness of the servant’s words
questions.explanation: The 'sharp sword' metaphor in Isaiah 49:2 highlights the cutting, powerful nature of the servant's prophetic speech which pierces hearts and brings truth.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:7 mentions kings and princes worshiping the servant. Which Old Testament figure is closely paralleled by this portrayal of exaltation and worship?
options: King David
Moses
Joseph
Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: King David
questions.explanation: The exaltation and worship by kings and princes in Isaiah 49:7 parallels King David’s role as chosen by God and honored by nations (2 Samuel 7).

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:22, God declares He will lift His hand to the Gentiles and set up His standard to the people. What cultural practice does this imagery evoke from the ancient Near East?
options: Raising a banner as a sign of gathering troops or protection
Offering a sacrifice to appease the gods
Building a tower as a symbol of strength
Writing a covenant on stone tablets
questions.correctAnswer: Raising a banner as a sign of gathering troops or protection
questions.explanation: The lifting of a hand and setting up a standard (banner) in Isaiah 49:22 evokes ancient military and protective symbolism where a banner called people to assemble and represented divine protection.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:11 uses the metaphor of making mountains a way and highways exalted. What broader biblical theme does this motif represent?
options: God’s provision for His people’s return and restoration
The destruction of enemies through natural disasters
The building of the temple in Jerusalem
The conquest of the Promised Land
questions.correctAnswer: God’s provision for His people’s return and restoration
questions.explanation: The imagery of exalted highways and made mountains a way in Isaiah 49:11 symbolizes God preparing a way for His people’s restoration and return from exile.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49:16 use physical imagery to communicate God’s intimate care for His people?
options: By stating He has graven them on the palms of His hands
By describing them as a vineyard cared for by a gardener
By comparing them to precious jewels in a crown
By likening them to sheep guided by a shepherd
questions.correctAnswer: By stating He has graven them on the palms of His hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:16 uses the metaphor of engraving on the palms of God’s hands to show that His people are always before Him, signifying permanent remembrance and protection.

questions.question: True or False: In Isaiah 49:4, the servant expresses doubt about God’s judgment but ultimately trusts that his work is with God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:4 shows the servant feeling his labor might be in vain but affirming that his judgment and work are with the LORD, expressing trust amid doubt.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:13 calls on the heavens, earth, and mountains to sing and be joyful. This use of nature to express joy is an example of what biblical literary technique?
options: Personification
Hyperbole
Allegory
Parable
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:13 personifies creation by ascribing singing and joy to heavens, earth, and mountains to express the magnitude of God’s comfort and mercy.

questions.question: The phrase 'to bring Jacob again to him' in Isaiah 49:5 primarily refers to what Old Testament theme?
options: The restoration of Israel after exile
The establishment of the Davidic monarchy
The giving of the Law at Mount Sinai
The conquest of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: The restoration of Israel after exile
questions.explanation: The phrase in Isaiah 49:5 aligns with the prophetic theme of restoration and return of Israel (Jacob) to God after periods of judgment and exile.

questions.question: Which verse in Isaiah 49 directly challenges the question, 'Shall the prey be taken from the mighty, or the lawful captive delivered?' and what is the answer provided?
options: Isaiah 49:25; Yes, God will contend and save
Isaiah 49:24; No, captives remain captive
Isaiah 49:26; Only the mighty can save
Isaiah 49:23; Kings will refuse to help
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 49:25; Yes, God will contend and save
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:24-25 poses and answers that God will rescue the captives and contend on behalf of His people.

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:10, what theological concept is symbolized by the promise that the people shall not hunger nor thirst and will be led by springs of water?
options: Divine provision and guidance
Physical healing
Judgment on enemies
The establishment of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Divine provision and guidance
questions.explanation: The imagery in Isaiah 49:10 represents God’s sustaining care and leadership for His people, a common biblical theme of spiritual and physical provision.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:23 describes kings and queens bowing and licking the dust of the servant’s feet. What does this imagery signify in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Complete submission and honor to the servant
A ritual of mourning
A curse invoked upon enemies
A common greeting between rulers
questions.correctAnswer: Complete submission and honor to the servant
questions.explanation: In the ancient Near East, bowing and licking the dust symbolized total submission and reverence, indicating the servant's exalted status in Isaiah 49:23.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:12 mentions people coming from 'the land of Sinim.' Scholars debate this location. Which of the following is a common scholarly interpretation regarding 'Sinim'?
options: A reference to a distant land possibly linked to southern regions such as Egypt or even China
A poetic name for Babylon
A symbolic term for the underworld
A city in Edom
questions.correctAnswer: A reference to a distant land possibly linked to southern regions such as Egypt or even China
questions.explanation: The term 'Sinim' in Isaiah 49:12 is debated but often thought to indicate a far-off land, possibly southern Egypt or even distant lands such as China, emphasizing the global scope of God’s salvation.

questions.question: Which of the following best captures the authorial intent behind Isaiah 49:8's promise to give the servant as a 'covenant of the people' to establish the earth?
options: To show the servant’s role in universal restoration and divine promise fulfillment
To predict the building of a political alliance
To highlight the servant’s military conquest
To describe the servant’s priestly duties
questions.correctAnswer: To show the servant’s role in universal restoration and divine promise fulfillment
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:8 emphasizes the servant’s mission to be a covenant to all people, reflecting a universal restoration and fulfillment of God's promises beyond Israel.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 49 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 49 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:1, when did the LORD call the servant and make mention of his name?
options: From the womb
At his birth
When he began his ministry
At his baptism
questions.correctAnswer: From the womb
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:1 states that the LORD called the servant from the womb and made mention of his name from the bowels of his mother, indicating God's sovereign calling before birth. This is consistent with Jeremiah 1:5 and Galatians 1:15, where God calls His servants before birth.

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:2, the servant's mouth is compared to what?
options: A sharp sword
A gentle breeze
A roaring lion
A healing balm
questions.correctAnswer: A sharp sword
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:2 describes the servant's mouth as a sharp sword, symbolizing the power and authority of his words. Hebrews 4:12 and Ephesians 6:17 similarly describe the word of God as a sword, highlighting divine judgment and truth.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:3 identifies the servant as whom?
options: Israel, in whom God will be glorified
A foreign prophet
A king of Babylon
A priest of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Israel, in whom God will be glorified
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:3 calls the servant 'Israel,' God’s servant in whom He will be glorified. This reflects the servant motif representing God's chosen people and ultimately the Messiah (Romans 9:4, Philippians 2:9-11).

questions.question: What complaint does the servant express in Isaiah 49:4?
options: That his labor has been in vain
That he is forgotten by God
That he is persecuted by kings
That he lacks wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: That his labor has been in vain
questions.explanation: In Isaiah 49:4, the servant laments that his labor and strength have been spent in vain, yet he trusts that his judgment and work are with the LORD. This echoes the sufferings of the righteous servant as in Psalm 69:9 and Hebrews 12:3.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:6, what additional mission is the servant given beyond restoring Israel?
options: To be a light to the Gentiles
To build a temple in Jerusalem
To lead a military conquest
To become a king over all nations
questions.correctAnswer: To be a light to the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:6 states the servant is appointed not only to restore Israel but also to be a light to the Gentiles, bringing salvation to the ends of the earth. This mission is echoed in Acts 13:47 and Luke 2:32, showing the servant’s universal redemptive role.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:7 indicates that despite being despised by man, who will worship the servant?
options: Kings and princes
The children of Israel only
Foreign merchants
The priests of Baal
questions.correctAnswer: Kings and princes
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:7 prophesies that kings and princes, despite the servant being despised, will rise and worship because of the LORD’s faithfulness. This theme is reflected in Psalm 72:11 and Philippians 2:10-11 concerning Christ’s exaltation.

questions.question: What promise does the LORD make in Isaiah 49:8 concerning the servant’s role in salvation?
options: He will preserve and give him as a covenant to the people
He will grant him riches and power
He will make him a judge over nations
He will hide him from all enemies
questions.correctAnswer: He will preserve and give him as a covenant to the people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:8 promises that in an acceptable time, God will preserve the servant and give him as a covenant to the people, establishing the earth and restoring desolate heritages. This covenantal role aligns with Jeremiah 31:31-34 and Luke 22:20.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:10, what blessings does God promise to those led by Him?
options: They shall not hunger nor thirst
They shall be given great wealth
They shall conquer their enemies
They shall live in palaces
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not hunger nor thirst
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:10 assures that those whom God leads will not hunger or thirst, nor suffer heat or sun, reflecting God’s providential care. This is consistent with John 6:35 where Jesus is the bread of life, and Revelation 7:16-17 about God’s eternal provision.

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:13, what reasons are given for the heavens, earth, and mountains to sing and rejoice?
options: Because the LORD has comforted His people and shown mercy
Because the temple has been rebuilt
Because Israel has conquered its enemies
Because the harvest is plentiful
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD has comforted His people and shown mercy
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:13 calls creation to rejoice because the LORD has comforted His people and shown mercy to the afflicted. This theme of God’s comfort is echoed in 2 Corinthians 1:3-4 and Psalm 34:18.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 49:15 describe God’s compassion compared to a mother's compassion for her child?
options: God's compassion is greater; He will never forget His people
God sometimes forgets like a mother might
God’s compassion is less because He is just
God’s compassion is conditional on obedience
questions.correctAnswer: God's compassion is greater; He will never forget His people
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:15 uses the analogy of a mother’s compassion to emphasize that even if a mother could forget, God will never forget His people, showing His unfailing love. This is consistent with Psalm 103:13 and John 10:27-29.

questions.question: What metaphor does Isaiah 49:16 use to express God's intimate care for His people?
options: He has graven them upon the palms of His hands
He has built a wall around them
He has written their names in the sky
He has placed them on a high mountain
questions.correctAnswer: He has graven them upon the palms of His hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:16 depicts God as engraving His people on the palms of His hands, symbolizing constant remembrance and protection. This imagery aligns with Psalm 139:17-18 and Revelation 2:17 where believers are marked by God.

questions.question: Isaiah 49:22 speaks of God's promise to the Gentiles. What does He say He will do?
options: Lift up His hand to the Gentiles and bring the sons and daughters of Israel in their arms
Send plagues upon the Gentiles
Hide Israel from the Gentiles
Make the Gentiles enemies of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Lift up His hand to the Gentiles and bring the sons and daughters of Israel in their arms
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:22 promises God will extend His hand to the Gentiles, raising a standard for them, and they will carry Israel’s sons and daughters, illustrating the inclusion of Gentiles in salvation. This is echoed in Romans 11:11-12 and Ephesians 2:14-18.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 49:23, who will act as nursing fathers and mothers to Israel, and how will they show humility?
options: Kings and queens; bowing down and licking the dust of Israel’s feet
The priests and Levites; offering sacrifices
Foreign merchants; trading goods
All nations; sending gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Kings and queens; bowing down and licking the dust of Israel’s feet
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:23 states that kings and queens will be nursing parents to Israel, humbling themselves by bowing and licking dust at her feet, symbolizing reverence and submission. This theme is reflected in Psalm 72:9 and Philippians 2:9-11.

questions.question: What assurance does Isaiah 49:25 give concerning the captives of the mighty?
options: They shall be taken away and the prey delivered
They will remain captive forever
They shall be forgotten by God
They must redeem themselves
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be taken away and the prey delivered
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:25 assures that even captives of the mighty will be rescued and prey delivered, as God contends on behalf of His people. This reflects God's salvation in Psalm 34:17 and Luke 4:18.

questions.question: In Isaiah 49:26, how will God deal with those who oppress His people?
options: Feed them with their own flesh and make them drunk with their own blood
Ignore their oppression
Forgive them immediately
Send them to exile without judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Feed them with their own flesh and make them drunk with their own blood
questions.explanation: Isaiah 49:26 vividly describes God’s judgment on oppressors, feeding them with their own flesh and making them drunk with their own blood, symbolizing divine retribution. This is consistent with Ezekiel 39:17-20 and Revelation 14:20.
